channel.title: Java Key Codes
channel.description:
What's up.
I'm making something that takes a string as an argument and uses java.awt.Robot to type out each letter.
I don't want to code in all the keycodes myself.
Is there a way to programatically find the keycode of a character?
Thanks.

item.title: Java Key Codes
item.dc:creator: @the_bank the bank
item.description:
@the_bank wrote:

OP is a retard

Read full topic

item.title: Java Key Codes
item.dc:creator: @Aftermath_961 Aftermath
item.description:
@Aftermath_961 wrote:

[quote=“chri5, post:23, topic:370114”][quote author=Repentless link=topic=466234.msg3410378#msg3410378 date=1290637426]

KeyStroke.getKeyStroke(‘a’) gives me “typed a”

Sorry isn’t that the intended function? Or am I missing something?

I’m looking for the virtual key code.

http://download.oracle.com/javase/1.4.2/docs/api/java/awt/AWTKeyStroke.html#getKeyCode()

This?

Maybe I’m being stupid but I don’t see how that helps. Yes I can get the keycode of a key event but what I’m trying to do is get keycodes so I can send key events.
[/quote]

int key = KeyStroke.getKeyStroke('a').getKeyCode();

That doesn’t actually work in this context, it will always return 0 here.

Read full topic

item.title: Java Key Codes
item.dc:creator: @chri5 chri5
item.description:
@chri5 wrote:

[quote=“Repentless, post:15, topic:370114”][quote author=chri5 link=topic=466234.msg3410225#msg3410225 date=1290629526]

KeyStroke.getKeyStroke(‘a’) gives me “typed a”

Sorry isn’t that the intended function? Or am I missing something?

I’m looking for the virtual key code.

http://download.oracle.com/javase/1.4.2/docs/api/java/awt/AWTKeyStroke.html#getKeyCode()

This?
[/quote]

Maybe I’m being stupid but I don’t see how that helps. Yes I can get the keycode of a key event but what I’m trying to do is get keycodes so I can send key events.[/quote]

int key = KeyStroke.getKeyStroke('a').getKeyCode();

Read full topic

item.title: Java Key Codes
item.dc:creator: @lawl lawl
item.description:
@lawl wrote:

[quote=“Nueb35, post:21, topic:370114”]like many have stated above, REFLECTION!

  1. call [/tt]KeyEvent.class.getDeclaredFields()[/tt]
  2. loop through its fields in search of VK_{insert letter/number/etc here}
  3. get its value
  4. ???
  5. profit[/quote]
    r u srsly retarded

item.title: Java Key Codes
item.dc:creator: @Repentless Repentless
item.description:
@Repentless wrote:

[quote=“pkedpker, post:19, topic:370114”]Thanks although yah SendKeys sucks balls you have to focus on the window and it loses focus when a event is triggered on your computer.

I’ve trying to make it use SendMessage() api but i can’t find a decent FindWindowEx api for VB.NET.

All forums say don’t use FindWindow in VB.NET use Runtime.GetProcesses() or some shit like that, but they don’t know jack about children handles.

As for your problem create a hashmap of all possible keys and keycodes, other then that chri5 got you i guess ;D[/quote]

The whole idea behind the thread was to find a way other than a hashmap or similar solutions… but I’ve decided to move on to C++ and leave POS Java behind.

Read full topic

item.title: Java Key Codes
item.dc:creator: @pkedpker pkedpker
item.description:
@pkedpker wrote:

Thanks although yah SendKeys sucks balls you have to focus on the window and it loses focus when a event is triggered on your computer.

I’ve trying to make it use SendMessage() api but i can’t find a decent FindWindowEx api for VB.NET.

All forums say don’t use FindWindow in VB.NET use Runtime.GetProcesses() or some shit like that, but they don’t know jack about children handles.

As for your problem create a hashmap of all possible keys and keycodes, other then that chri5 got you i guess ;D

Read full topic

item.title: Java Key Codes
item.dc:creator: @Repentless Repentless
item.description:
@Repentless wrote:

[quote=“pkedpker, post:16, topic:370114”]VK_KEY’s are listed on the ASCII chart
http://www.cs.utk.edu/~pham/ascii_table.jpg

so translating the char in java to it’s numeric value gives you the KeyEvent.VK_value in most cases if not all?

I don’t understand how lowercase letters behave with this systems probably triggered after capslock VK_key

are you building a keylogger?

I am building a tetris bot today from boredom, got the AI all ready but sending keystrokes to the game window is giving me problems haha… I’m using VB.NET[/quote]

http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/system.windows.forms.sendkeys.aspx

And I’m not making a keylogger. I’m sending keystrokes, not recording them.

Read full topic

item.title: Java Key Codes
item.dc:creator: @pkedpker pkedpker
item.description:
@pkedpker wrote:

VK_KEY’s are listed on the ASCII chart
http://www.cs.utk.edu/~pham/ascii_table.jpg

so translating the char in java to it’s numeric value gives you the KeyEvent.VK_value in most cases if not all?

I don’t understand how lowercase letters behave with this systems probably triggered after capslock VK_key

are you building a keylogger?

I am building a tetris bot today from boredom, got the AI all ready but sending keystrokes to the game window is giving me problems haha… I’m using VB.NET

Read full topic

item.title: Java Key Codes
item.dc:creator: @Repentless Repentless
item.description:
@Repentless wrote:

[quote=“chri5, post:6, topic:370114”]reflection!

or not be lazy and

public static int getKeycode(char c) { switch (c) { case 'a': return KeyEvent.VK_A; break; case 'b': return KeyEvent.VK_B; break; case 'c': return KeyEvent.VK_C; break; //etc case ' ': return KeyEvent.VK_SPACE; break; default: return -1; break; } }[/quote]

This is exactly what I’m trying to avoid…

KeyStroke.getKeyStroke(‘a’) gives me “typed a”

Read full topic

item.title: Java Key Codes
item.dc:creator: @nueb35 Nueb35
item.description:
@nueb35 wrote:

use reflection to do it, or use KeyStroke class

http://download.oracle.com/javase/6/docs/api/javax/swing/KeyStroke.html

Read full topic

item.title: Java Key Codes
item.dc:creator: @chri5 chri5
item.description:
@chri5 wrote:

[quote=“Taharok, post:7, topic:370114”][quote author=chri5 link=topic=466234.msg3409914#msg3409914 date=1290614222]
reflection!

or not be lazy and

public static int getKeycode(char c) { switch (c) { case 'a': return KeyEvent.VK_A; break; case 'b': return KeyEvent.VK_B; break; case 'c': return KeyEvent.VK_C; break; //etc case ' ': return KeyEvent.VK_SPACE; break; default: return -1; break; } }
[/quote]

Ps, you can’t break the switch after the value’s returned. ;)[/quote]
Sorry, that’s what typing code in the reply box does

Read full topic

item.title: Java Key Codes
item.dc:creator: @Repentless Repentless
item.description:
@Repentless wrote:

Miss Silabsoft:

http://download.oracle.com/javase/1.4.2/docs/api/java/awt/event/KeyEvent.html

I can use this to find out key codes, but that’s not the problem. I don’t want to have to hard code a lot of stuff into my class.

I want something like getkeycode(‘a’) that returns the virtual key code.

Hi Speljohan!
